conversation.content: Hey coach, we need to [groan] talk about what happened at practice today.

Yeah, I know, um, that was rough. Look, I get that everyone's frustrated about losing three games in a row, but the way some people were, you know, talking to each other out there—that's not who we are as a team, honestly.
Well, James started it when he, er, called out Tyler for missing that pass, I mean, it just escalated from there.

Right, so, I saw that whole thing go down, and actually, James was out of line. But Tyler throwing his helmet? That's not acceptable either, you know? We're supposed to be setting an example for the JV kids who were watching us practice today, basically.
I guess, um, everyone's just feeling the pressure, especially with playoffs coming up and, well, we're not even close to ready.

The thing is, pressure's part of the game, right? I've been captain for two years now and, hmm, I've seen teams fall apart over less. But I've also seen teams, like, pull together when it matters most—we just need to figure out which one we want to be, honestly.
You really think we can turn this around?

Absolutely. Remember sophomore year when we were, uh, dead last going into October? We ended up making it to regionals because we stopped fighting each other and, well, started fighting for each other instead. That's what made the difference, you know?
That was different though, er, we had Marcus then, and he was, like, basically our best player.

Marcus was good, yeah, but actually, you're selling yourself short here. You've scored more goals this season than he did that entire year, I mean, the stats don't lie. It's just that, um, nobody's playing as a unit right now, you know?
So what do we do? I mean, how do we, uhh, fix this before it's too late?

First, we're having a team meeting tomorrow, and everyone's going to [angry] air their grievances properly, not by throwing equipment around like, err, toddlers. Then we're doing trust exercises—yeah I know they're cheesy but, honestly, this team needs to remember we're supposed to have each other's backs.
Trust exercises? Come on, that's not going to work with this group.

Hey, I did the same thing with the volleyball team last year when they asked me to help out, and um, they went from constant drama to winning districts. Sometimes you need to, like, get back to basics and remember why you started playing in the first place, you know?
I started playing because, well, my dad wanted me to, honestly. He played in college and, er, always dreamed I'd follow in his footsteps.

And what about now? Because I watch you out there during practice when you think no one's looking, and uhh, you light up when you nail a perfect shot. That's not about your dad anymore—that's all you, I mean, that joy is real, actually.
I never really [gasp softly] thought about it that way before.

That's what being captain taught me, you know? Half this job is, basically, helping people see what they can't see in themselves. You're one of our strongest players, but more importantly, err, the younger kids look up to you—they need to see you believing in this team.
You're pretty good at this whole [flirtatious] leadership thing, you know that?

Thanks. Now quit flirting and help me figure out how to get James and Tyler to actually talk to each other tomorrow without starting World War Three—I'm thinking we make them lead the trust fall exercise together.
